View Matrices¶

class pygly.view_matrix.ViewMatrix(aspect_ratio, near_clip, far_clip)[source]¶

Base class for View Matrix objects.

Handles a number of common functions.

__init__(aspect_ratio, near_clip, far_clip)[source]¶

Creates a view matrix object.

Args:
aspect_ratio: The aspect ratio of the viewport. This can be updated at any time. near_clip: The nearest distance to render objects. far_clip: The furthest distance to render objects.
Raises:
ValueError: Raised if the far clip is <= the near clip.
aspect_ratio[source]¶

The aspect ratio.

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

create_ray_from_ratio_point(point)[source]¶

Returns a local ray cast from the camera co-ordinates at ‘point’.

The ray will begin at the near clip plane. The ray is relative to the origin. The ray will project from the near clip plane down the -Z plane toward the far clip plane.

The ray is in intertial space and must be transformed to the objects intended translation and orientation.

Args:
point: The 2D point, relative to this view matrix, to project a ray from. A list of 2 float values. [0.0, 0.0] is the Bottom Left. [viewport.width, viewport.height] is the Top Right.
Returns:
A ray consisting of 2 vectors (shape = 2,3).
far_clip[source]¶

The far clip value.

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

matrix[source]¶

The current view matrix.

near_clip[source]¶

The near clip value.

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

on_change_aspect_ratio(aspect_ratio)[source]¶

Updates the aspect ratio.

Used to hook into Viewport events.

Args:
aspect_ratio: The new aspect ratio to set.
pop_view_matrix()[source]¶

Pops the current viewport off the matrix stack.

push_view_matrix()[source]¶

Pushes the frustrum matrix onto the projection viewport.

Updates the matrix if self.dirty == True Sets the glMatrixMode to GL_PROJECTION. It is up to the caller to change this after calling this function.

Manages a standard projection view matrix.

Used by viewports and camera’s to render a scene using a standard perspective view.

calculate_point_on_plane(point, distance)[source]¶

Calculates the absolute X,Y co-ordinates on a plane ‘distance’ away from the origin of the frustrum.

Returns:
A NumPy array of the point as a 2D vector.
create_ray_from_ratio_point(point)[source]¶

Returns a local ray cast from the camera co-ordinates at ‘point’.

The ray will begin at the near clip plane. The ray is relative to the origin. The ray will project from the near clip plane down the -Z plane toward the far clip plane.

The ray is in intertial space and must be transformed to the objects intended translation and orientation.

Args:
point: The 2D point, relative to this view matrix, to project a ray from. A list of 2 float values. [0.0, 0.0] is the Bottom Left. [viewport.width, viewport.height] is the Top Right.
Returns:
A ray represented by a NumPy array of 2 x 3D vector. The first vector is the ray origin, the second is the ray direction.
fov[source]¶

The Field of View of the view matrix.

Note

This is an @property decorated method which allows retrieval and assignment of the scale value.

class pygly.orthogonal_view_matrix.OrthogonalViewMatrix(aspect_ratio, scale, near_clip=1.0, far_clip=100.0)[source]¶

Manages an orthogonal view matrix.

Used by viewports and camera’s to render a scene using an orthogonal perspective.

__init__(aspect_ratio, scale, near_clip=1.0, far_clip=100.0)[source]¶

Initialises an orthographic (2D) view matrix.

Args:
aspect_ratio: The aspect ratio of the viewport. This can be updated at any time. scale: The scale to apply to the width and height of the orthogonal view. The dimensions of the view matrix (left, right, bottom, top) are calculated as follows: height = 1.0 * scale.y width = 1.0 * scale.z * viewport aspect ratio near_clip: The nearest distance to render objects. far_clip: The furthest distance to render objects.
bounds()[source]¶

Returns the maximum extents of the orthographic view based on the current viewport and the set scale.

Returns:
The bounds as a tuple (left, right, bottom, top)

point: The 2D point, relative to this view matrix, to project a ray from. A list of 2 float values. [0.0, 0.0] is the Bottom Left. [viewport.width, viewport.height] is the Top Right.
